The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations
What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List:
Critical thinking surrounding landscape scale conservation
Introduction to some of the software used to help with landscape scale conservation
This is a technical class--you learn geospatial modeling at a high level. Helpful, but difficult if you don't have a foundation in GIS or R.
So many. I felt it was a great class for conservationists to best familiarize themselves with conservation strategies.

Technical skills:
GIS
R Coding
maxent
circuitscape
population viability assessment

non-technical:
landscape level view
working with people

Species distribution, viability, and fitness
Effective ways to protect species
Negotiation tools for land allocation
Basic understanding of R, Maxent, and Circuitscape
Improved practical use of GIS
GIS MAXENT CURCUITSCAPE. Os gave incredible lectures

This course requires you to learn/practice a series of software packages that you may or may not have been familiar with before...it's a great way to practice ArcMap and R, and learn Maxent and Circuitscape.

There was a lot of software that I had never heard of before that we used in this course, like Maxent and CircuitScape. We also applied GIS to a lot of what we were doing with these softwares. I don't know if any other courses teach these softwares as well. 

Therefore, if this class isn't taught next semester, there needs to be a course similar to it, one where you can still be exposed to these softwares.

I learned how to use some of the technical tools - GIS, R, Circuitscape, MaxEnt - that are invaluable to conservation planning.  I also developed a greater understanding of why conservation is so complicated and how the good intentions of scientists and policymakers can go awry due to lack of good data and an appreciation for how elements of an ecosystem interact at a landscape scale,
Literally everything I needed to know. This was finally the course I needed FES to provide in the conservation curriculum. Os is also an amazing lecturer.
I developed some important technical skills, the applications of which were connected with real world issues. We didn't just learn how to use the tools, we also learned their limitations and caveats.
I explored a new way of looking at problems. I also learned about a few new softwares (R, Maxent, Circuitscape) and was able to play around with them.

I learned so much from this course, both technically and theoretically. On the technical side, I have a much deeper understanding of the challenges of data collection and analysis species-focused conservation assessments and a grasp on the major computing tools (GIS, R, Maxent, CircuitScape) used in the field.  On the theoretical side, the lectures, focused on coexistence landscapes and ways of addressing conservation challenges, shaped the way I think about conservation work and land use priorities.

There were two big takeaways from this course. The first was about the most frequently used methods of predicting species distribution and projecting future trends. The second was about the utility of science in decision-making, while keeping in mind that people and diverse sets of values have just as much importance in decisions about how to use and protect the landscape.
Species distribution modeling and landscape ecology.

I gained an understanding of what landscape-level planning is, and of the various modern tools that can be used to assess species viability, habitat suitability and species distribution, connectivity, and potential responses to climate change, and of how these findings can be incorporated into a larger conservation management plan - in this case, specifically in the context of a national park. Beyond the assignments, though, the class lectures delved into deeper understandings of how we go about conservation and how we can seek to reconcile conservation needs with that of development priorities. Overall, I think this course was a good foundation and one I hope to build on in further study.
I am very happy with what I learned in terms of conservation science. I am disappointed with the amount I learned in respect to applying it through the different softwares and assignments.
Similarly.
Very well
It went above and beyond. Amazing class
Very well
Well high expectations high degree of learning opportunities
They met my expectations. I did not realize how much time it would take to troubleshoot all of this technology, but I'm glad I learned it.

I knew this class was going to be a lot of work, and I was not disappointed. It was very, very stressful, and involved a lot of research, but I still feel like I learned a lot. Aside from the many software and computer programs we used, the class also talked a lot about current conservation, and whether there needs to be changes to the way we try and protect land and animals, and how do you balance that with local communities.
I learned a lot more on the technical front than I expected I would.  Os's lectures about inter-species relationships were just what I'd hoped for when I signed up for the course.
Again, this was everything I needed and more.
Exceeded them.

In theory they aligned very well but in practice I didn't really get the skills and knowledge I hoped for. I mostly just learned that things existed and struggled through assignments that used the tools but I didn't really learn how to use any of the tools.
They exceeded expectations.

This course exceeded my expectations. I feel much more prepared to have informed discussions about how to manage land and work with both scientists and other types of participants about what is critical, desirable, or advantageous for them and their needs.
The course surpassed expectations.

When starting the class, I had a general idea of the sort of analytical tools we would be using in our assignments, and definitely left the class with a sense of how these tools can be applied, if not a real sense of mastery of them. While I think I learned a lot from this class, I'm not sure it really met my expectations in understanding how to go about such projects "in the real world." While our semester-long project was centered around Jasper National Park, and while we had a call early in the semester, this failed to become the sort of direct client project that I think many students had hoped it would be, and this lack of insight into what they wanted and also in some cases the lack of clear information contributed to the project feeling a lot more than just a class project, rather than a real-world application of the tools and knowledge we were learning about.

The content about conservation science and landscape planning was great. 

The level of instruction about the assignments and how to apply these principles needs more work. First, the timing is off. For example, we had a class focused on our 4th assignment before spring break when we were working on the 3rd assignment that was due after break. This can be fixed by a simple re-ordering of classes.

I would recommend a few classes focusing specifically on how to go about the technical sides to the project. Time was unnecessarily wasted trying to figure out how to make the software work instead of actually learning about how to apply the outputs from the software. For example, there was a problem with the R code for assignment #3 and for people who do not know R, we did not have the skills to know how to fix this. This does not need to be recreated each year. Just send the code that worked last class to the next class. There should be a more step-by-step guidelines for the assignments- this would focus the learning on the data and how it can be utilized.

The class also needs more technical support. One TA is not enough due to the high level of errors. Perhaps if there was a step-by-step guide, one TA would be  enough but if the class is kept as it is now, there needs to be another TA.

The timing of the assignments and the lectures was misaligned. I'd like more instruction about the overall project at the beginning of the semester. That being said, the class is definitely worth it if you are going into conservation, wildlife, science, land management, etc.
Took much time and effort. I thought better coordination with client could have been improved.

this is the most well organized class I've taken at FES. the lectures were thought provoking and filled with important information. The end product and assignments will help me in my career outside of FES
The course is very complete, and provides both science and policy concepts for species conservation.
More in class work time to get help on small fixes that otherwise take hours

The final paper is actually quite different from the other assignments and it feels a bit rushed at the end. There was also a bit of a disconnect between the timing of workshops when we were learning new software and when we actually had to use the software for homework assignments. Other than a stressful final project, I'm very happy with the course.

As discussed previously, I liked that the course questions current conservation strategies, and posed alternatives to how scientists tackle conservation efforts.

A strong weakness is the lack of clear requirements needed of students before they take this course. This class lists GIS as a skill that is beneficial for students to have before taking this course. Before shopping period started, I asked the professor which GIS should students know about (vector vs raster) and he said either is fine. This turned out not to be accurate. I came in with only vector GIS experience, and most (if not all) of the GIS work was raster-based. Vector and raster are very different, and there were a lot of tools that we had to use in GIS that I was not familiar with. Yes the TA and my group members were there to ask questions, but I still feel the professor should have been more clear about what GIS knowledge was needed.

We also used R, and while students may have been able to get away with not knowing R before taking this course, I think making it clear that knowing a little about R before taking this class would also have been very beneficial.

The class is extremely well-taught by Os and gives students many technical skills to make them more effective conservationists and (I suspect) more attractive candidates for employment. 

The course workload is, in my opinion, greater than what I associate with 4 credits.  It certainly required more time than Ecosystems and Landscapes, which is worth 5 credits.  I also found Guiseppe's guest lectures (to familiarize us with some of the programs we needed for our assignments) to be pretty terrible.  He was difficult to understand, particularly since many of us were learning about these complex concepts for the first time.  He moved through the material much too quickly and seemed to assume that we were already familiar with the basics of the programs being discussed which was not the case for all but one of the first years.  These technical lectures were also staggered oddly out of sync with our assignments.  For example, we would learn about Circuitscape (for assignment 3) while we were still struggling to complete assignment 2, which required us to work with MaxEnt.  By the time assignment 3 actually came around, it had been weeks since our Circuitscape lecture with Giuseppe and much of what he had discussed was hard to remember.

Strengths: lectures, assignments 

Weaknesses: not enough office hours with the TAs, could have used more workshopping of R for the last assignment

Really great course, but there's so much packed into it. I think it could be expanded to two or three course. I could have spent my whole time here learning what was taught in this class. There need to be more classes like it because its kind of absurd this is all packed into a single course offered every two years. Students interested in wildlife and landscape conservation just don't have the opportunities needed to become well-rounded practitioners. That being said, the class was extremely difficult if you didn't have a strong grounding in some very specific prerequisites (which was most of the class). There was a lot to learn a tiny time period and many of the students didn't feel they had the tools they needed. That being said, this is NOT the professors fault. I think F&ES needs to do a better job of offering similar classes that build off each other.

This course is one of the best I have taken at FES. The only thing I would recommend is finding a new GIS instructor, or more tightly regulating how the current GIS instructor teaches.

Os delegates the GIS portions of the class to the two teaching assistants. Ethan Miller was an amazing TA overall, but the task of actually teaching how to perform the GIS and spatial modeling work fell to the other TA (who specialized in GIS). However, the GIS instructor did not perform adequately. He failed to explain how particular spatial distribution programs that were required for assignments worked, preferring instead to lecture about how to perform these same procedures via coding practices in R. This would have been fine if students understood what these programs were and how they worked, but he skipped over those instructions and went straight to R instead. This left students confused and unable to actually perform their assignments -- because they had no idea what the programs were supposed to be doing. R was unnecessary for most of these assignments, so students would instead follow instructions online for how to use these programs. Once they hit a bug or obstacle, they would go to the GIS teaching fellow for help, who would instead lecture them about using R instead and make them start over. This created 2 problems: first, the students would be unable to figure out what they were supposed to do; second, even if a student figured out how to replicate their work in R they would still be unable to pass the bug or obstacle they had hit in the first place.

I recommend a more structured approach to the assignments, particularly when teaching Maxent. The first assignment using Maxent (assignment 2) should be explained using only the Maxent GUI provided by the American Museum of Natural History and with ArcGIS as the method to create the environmental variables. R should never be mentioned at this stage. This will allow the students to figure out what the program does and how it works with methods that are more familiar and user-friendly. Then, once this foundation is in place, the second Maxent assignment (assignment 4) should then bring in how to use R (since it is impossible to do this assignment without R). Students will understand what they are doing and will be able to focus on how to translate their understanding of the Maxent GUI to the R code.

Strengths: The course is meant to be very practical and actually look at hard skills and tools that you could use in the real world. 

Weaknesses: Students aren't really taught how to use any of the tools, they are merely told that the tools exist and then thrown into an assignment that uses the tools. So many of us spent WAAAAAY too long trying to just figure out how to use a software which is simply a waste of our time. We would have spent a fraction of the time and learned more if we would have first been shown how to actually use the software and then given the assignment. I don't really feel like I learned any of the tools. I simply fudged them until something came out without really understanding or being able to replicate it in the future. Also, there should be like 3 TAs for the course and they should all know how to use the software. It is really unhelpful when the TA can't really help you and when you are really struggling to figure something out but there's no one available to help.

The lectures are largely theoretical, while the homework assignments are technical and not always supported by the lectures. The workshops, designed to support the technical work of the homework, were largely unhelpful. The course follows a "learn by doing" model, which is great, except that many of the details of the computer programs we learned are specifics not easily figured out by experimentation (ex. specifics of input file formatting). The constant trial and error [messages] took the focus away from learning. More guidance on the technical aspects would have allowed deeper understanding of the concepts behind the tools. One of the challenges of this class is the broad range of skill sets that people come in with. If GIS and R prerequisites are not enforced, intro to GIS or R workshops should be mandatory for people who don't have any experience with those tools. The in-class workshops were consistently at the wrong level for many students in class and were frustrating and confusing rather than informative.

The strengths of this course are that it gives you a working familiarity with the most widespread methods for conservation science. The downside is that the course instructors do not teach the software or program materials themselves, so the students need to self-teach the programs to themselves. This was a double-edged, because it was extremely time-consuming and overwhelming to trouble-shoot, identify errors, and figure out how to process the data on our own, but by working through the kinks ourselves, we also learned how to process data and use the programs much more thoroughly.
An incredible diversity of tools. Perhaps more time on R related programming.

This class takes a LOT of time-More than other 4 credit classes. The extra time however, is not extra learning, but frustration with software and not knowing how to fix errors. I learned valuable concepts from this class that I will apply to my career but the class could use some restructuring
Don't take it unless you know GIS at a more than basic level.
take it.
The work and time is worth it. You will gain so much from this course.
Don't take more than 12 credits or 4 classes.
Be prepared for lot of extra hours work

There is a TON of work up front (when you basically have to learn everything there is to know about your species of interest) and then it gets a bit easier as time goes on but it still takes so much time. I easily spent half of my time this semester working on this course alone...and I overloaded on credits.  If you are looking for a course where you will get practical GIS experience and learn how to make species distribution models and habitat connectivity models, this is the course for you!

Make sure you know a little about raster before taking this course. You could probably get away with taking the raster course at the same time as this course, but that is a very heavy workload, so be careful. It may also be beneficial to know a little about R beforehand.

Even though the course has no listed prerequisites, I would strongly encourage students to be at least somewhat familiar with both R and raster GIS before taking this course (vector GIS a plus).  Our TA was extremely helpful in navigating all of the class's technical hurdles, but he was only one guy and most of us needed a lot of help.
This is one of the greatest classes I have taken at FES. If you are interested in working in conservation, you need this class. Finally something other than theory!
TAKE THIS CLASS. There's nothing like it if you're interested in practicing conservation.

I personally believe that this should be a required class for every person to go through FES. Failing that, if you are at all interested in wildlife, conservation, land management, or human-ecosystem conflict -- even just tangentially -- you MUST TAKE THIS CLASS. It is a lot of work, but it is 100% worth it.

However, you cannot treat this class as you would a class in undergrad. Procrastination and laziness will work against you. This is a course that will be crucial for future jobs in conservation and environmental protection, but if you fail to do the assignments it will work against you.

Be ready to put in a lot of time into the course. You will cover interesting material and learn about some really cool softwares but don't expect to actually learn how to use the softwares. You will simply struggle through it without really knowing what you are doing.

Be very careful with your group selection--make sure that there are people with experience in GIS and R in your group. If you don't have one of those skills, be prepared to take quick online tutorials or otherwise familiarize yourself with those skills. Give yourself lots of time to complete assignments.
This class takes a lot of time, so be prepared to dedicate a lot of time to the bi-weekly assignments. However, you will also get a lot out of the course.
Get ready to dig into the world of geospatial modeling. It will be a rewarding ride!

Professor Schmitz is a very knowledgeable instructor and gives great and thought-provoking lectures. However, unless the structure is revised in future, I found this class to not adequately prepare us to work on the assignments, and found my classmates and I frustrated in dealing with troubleshooting programs that we had been given minimal introduction to. I think the insights gained from this class can be great, and I think this class is absolutely necessary for anyone interested in practical conservation, and I think a reworking - one that better prepares students, gives better guidance to tackling the assigned questions, and better incorporates the really interesting lectures with the technical skills addressed in the assignments, would be fantastic.
